info.title: Enabling and disabling predictable naming scheme for network interfaces

abstract.para: When &slea; boots, network interfaces names are assigned. There are several strategies for assembling the interface names, mainly based on information obtained by probing network hardware devices. For security and administration purposes, it is crucial that the network interface names are predictable and persist system reboots and hardware changes. &systemd; together with udev rules introduce such stable and customizable naming scheme.

procedure.title: Enabling the naming scheme during the system installation

step.para: On the initial boot menu, enter net.ifnames=1 at the Boot Options prompt.
Confirm with and normally continue with the system installation.

procedure.title: Enabling the naming scheme on an already installed system

step.para: If the biosdevname package is installed, uninstall it.
Backup existing naming rules from /etc/udev/rules.d if they exist, for example:
Start the &yast; BootLoader module and append net.ifnames=1 to the kernel command-line. Confirm with OK and reboot the system.

If the system is using wicked as a network manager, align the configuration of network interfaces. You can use the yast lan module or rename /etc/sysconfig/network/ifcfg-* files accordingly. Then restart wicked.

section.title: Disabling predictable naming of network interfaces
section.para: To disable the predictable naming scheme, follow these steps:

step.para: Recover or create your own network interface naming scheme under /etc/udev/rules.d/, or reinstall the biosdevname package.
Start the &yast; BootLoader module, delete net.ifnames=1 if present, and append net.ifnames=0 to the kernel command-line. Confirm with OK.
